datafield.subfield: The random-bond Ising model in 2.01 and 3 dimensions

We consider the Ising model between 2 and 4 dimensions perturbed by quenched disorder in the strength of the interaction between nearby spins. In the interval 2 < d < 4 this disorder is a relevant perturbation that drives the system to a new fixed point of the renormalization group. At d = 2 such disorder is marginally irrelevant and can be studied using conformal perturbation theory. Combining conformal perturbation theory with recent results from the conformal bootstrap we compute some scaling exponents in an expansion around d = 2. If one trusts these computations also in d = 3, one finds results consistent with experimental data and Monte Carlo simulations. In addition, we perform a direct uncontrolled computation in d = 3 using new results for low-lying operator dimensions and OPE coefficients in the 3d Ising model. We compare these new methods with previous studies. Finally, we comment about the O(2) model in d = 3, where we predict a large logarithmic correction to the infrared scaling of disorder.
Weizmann Institute of Science - Rehovot 76100 - Israel
School of Natural Sciences - Institute for Advanced Study - Princeton - NJ 08540 - United States of America

We have a family of CFTs where δ is a continuous parameter that can be dialed to zero. Assuming the CFT data has an analytic power-series expansion in δ, we can then regulate the deformed theory by minimal subtraction. Specifically, we compute integrals like (, 3.6: #aaa6087eqn020) as a Laurent series in δ, and then add counterterms to cancel the poles. Physical observables (like IR scaling dimensions) will be scheme-independent, and in principle can be computed to arbitrary order using these techniques. An example of this situation is the usual Wilson-Fisher fixed point in 4-\epsilon dimensions. An example where the spacetime dimension does not vary is the Potts model where q is regarded as a continuous parameter

We might have an isolated CFT where δ just happens to be numerically small. In this case, the Laurent expansion of integrals like (, 3.6: #aaa6087eqn020) becomes ambiguous beyond the leading nonzero order. For example, without an expansion {{C}_{\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}}}(\delta )={{C}_{\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}}}(0)+\delta C_{\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}}^{\prime}(0)+\ldots, we cannot compute subleading terms in expressions involving {{C}_{\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}}}. In this scenario, minimal subtraction does not work. In fact, there is no scheme-independent expression for subleading corrections to physical observables in conformal perturbation theory. This is ultimately because the IR theory lives at the end of a nontrivial RG flow. To learn about it, we must perform a nonperturbative diagonalization of the full Hamiltonian, perhaps using conformal truncation methods [, 22: #aaa6087bib022] (see also more recent work [, 23: #aaa6087bib023]). An example of this situation is the disordered 3d Ising model, where \delta \approx 0.18. We will only be able to compute the leading nonzero contributions to disordered observables as an expansion in δ. In some cases these contributions occur at one loop, and in others at two loops, 8: #aaa6087fn8
If disorder is absent, then the coupling {{\lambda}^{2}} is marginally irrelevant, which, of course, is very well known

If we take pure Mean Field Theory (i.e. {{\lambda}^{2}}=0) in d = 4 and introduce disorder in temperature, the theory, at least initially, flows to strong coupling because the beta function for c2 is negative!

Disorder renders the coupling {{\lambda}^{2}} relevant, as the dimension of the interaction proportional to {{\lambda}^{2}} becomes {{ \Delta }_{{{\epsilon}^{2}}}}=4-12{{c}^{2}} (This follows from the first line in (, 4.5: #aaa6087eqn056), where the coefficient of {{\lambda}^{2}} is interpreted as usual to be -4+{{ \Delta }_{{{\epsilon}^{2}}}}.)

The one-loop approximation has a line of fixed points with 2{{c}^{2}}=3{{\lambda}^{2}}. This degeneracy disappears at higher orders. This line of fixed points is attractive for {{\lambda}^{2}} but unstable under disorder perturbations
See, for example [, 7: #aaa6087bib007], for higher order computations

Recently there was renewed activity and interest in the epsilon expansion, mostly motivated by potential applications for quantum phase transitions. See, for example [, 11: #aaa6087bib011,, 10: #aaa6087bib010-, 15: #aaa6087bib015], and references therein

It is instructive to re-derive the coefficient of the double-log from the expression (, 3.16: #aaa6087eqn030). There are three regions with a C_{\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}}^{2}/{{x}^{d}} singularity, namely, {{x}_{2}}\to \left\{0,1,\infty \right\}. But the cutoff in the x2 coordinate is rescaled by x1 because of the change of variables. Therefore we get the integral 3C_{\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}}^{2}{\int}^{}\frac{d|{{x}_{1}}|}{|{{x}_{1}}|}\log \left(|{{x}_{1}}|\right)\sim \frac{3C_{\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}\mathcal{O}}^{2}}{2}{{\log}^{2}}(\mu ), which precisely agrees with (, 3.11: #aaa6087eqn025)

As we explain in section, 8: #aaa6087s8, the disordered 3d Ising model can be also viewed as a perturbation around (very close to) the disordered O(2) model, thereby making it controllable

The conformal cross-ratio z in this configuration is given by z=\left(x\centerdot {{e}_{1}}\right)+\text{i}|x-\left(x\centerdot {{e}_{1}}\right){{e}_{1}}|, so that \mathcal{R}=\left\{z:|z|<1,|z|<|1-z|\right\}
In [, 31: #aaa6087bib031] the value {{C}_{\epsilon \epsilon \epsilon}}=1.45\pm 0.30 is obtained. In [, 32: #aaa6087bib032] the value {{C}_{\epsilon \epsilon \epsilon}}=1.32\pm 0.15 is reported

Note that in the d = 2 Ising model, {{C}_{\epsilon \epsilon \epsilon}}=0 by the Kramers-Wannier duality. In d = 4, Mean Field Theory is valid and we get (, 4.1: #aaa6087eqn052) {{C}_{\epsilon \epsilon \epsilon}}=2\sqrt{2}. The average of these two values is in the right ballpark for {{C}_{\epsilon \epsilon \epsilon}} in d = 3

When the quantity to be integrated is a linear function of Ising four-point functions, then it is possible to obtain direct bounds on the integral without computing the operators that appear in the four-point function [, 39: #aaa6087bib039]. An advantage of this approach is that we obtain precise error bars on the result. Here, we take the more straightforward route of approximating the entire function {{g}_{\sigma \epsilon \epsilon \sigma}}(u,v) first and then integrating

This operator is not turned on in the RG flow by {\sum}_{A\ne B}{{\epsilon}_{A}}{{\epsilon}_{B}} because it is protected by the \mathbb{Z}_{2}^{n} global symmetry of the replicated theory. It would be interesting to estimate its dimension and compare with bootstrap bounds
